awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding and Tuning the Molecular Arrangement and Charge Storage Properties of Textured Graphene-Ionic Liquid Interface
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical summary 
With the ever-increasing need for electrical power on demand, next generation energy storage devices (batteries and supercapacitors) must be designed that can support higher energy densities than current technologies. Therefore, new electrolyte and electrode materials must be explored that allow for higher electrolyte packing densities. To improve electrode/electrolyte interfaces, this project, supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research at NSF, seeks to understand how the structure of ionic liquids and their arrangement at electrode interfaces may be tuned by precisely controlling electrode geometry on the nanoscale. Single-layer graphene, a carbon-based material, just one-atom thick, which can function as a conductive electrode that is highly flexible, is used to created textured electrodes for this study. The research team investigates the influence of the electrode morphology on the organization of the ionic liquid electrolyte and how it impacts charge storage. In addition to exploring these fundamental science questions, this project supports the education and training of undergraduate and graduate students from diverse backgrounds, at the intersection of materials and surface science, contributing to the development of the energy sector work force in the U.S., by training students in cross-cutting research in a coordinated collaborative environment between the labs of the principle investigators at UIUC and TAMU. 

Technical summary
With this grant, supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research at NSF, the principle investigators (Espinosa-Marzal at UIUC and Batteas at TAMU) test the fundamental hypothesis that by controlling surface morphology and substrate-induced charge doping, along with the chemical composition of the ionic liquids, the local packing density of the liquid on graphene can be precisely modulated. This in turn is expected to afford better control over their charge storage properties. To fill the outlined knowledge gap, the team pursues three major lines of research. New methods to prepare graphene surfaces with precisely controlled charge doping and morphology from the atomic to the nanoscale are developed. In addition, the effects of substrate morphology and charge doping on the interfacial structure of ionic liquids and on the characteristics of the electrical double layer are investigated by Atomic Force Microscopy in an electrochemical cell. Furthermore, local and global electrochemical impedance spectroscopy are used to relate the electrical double layer to the differential capacitance of the textured interfaces. These studies allow determining the relative contributions of graphene roughness, charge doping and ionic liquid composition on the electrical double layer and its capacitance. The knowledge gained from this project is expected to enable control of the interfacial assembly of the liquids and stored charge through the modulation of the graphene texture.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Over the past 4 years, this NSF project, Collaborative Research: Understanding and Tuning the Molecular Arrangement and Charge Storage Properties of Textured Graphene-Ionic Liquid Interface, which was a collaboration between researchers at the University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign and Texas A&M University, has focused on addressing fundamental questions related to understanding how the structure of graphitic surfaces (and in particular graphene) could be architectured to control the interactions of ionic liquids with said surfaces. With key challenges in energy security facing the US, the development of high efficiency energy storage devices such as batteries and supercapacitors, can have a major impact on improved energy outcomes, and a broader impact of this work is the development of new approaches and fundamental scientific insight into potential technologies to control the structuring of ionic liquids for such purposes, which can have a significant impact on US energy independence and sustainability.

A key challenge in the project was the design of graphene electrode substrates where the interaction of the graphene with the substrate could be tuned by controlling surfaces roughness, as well as by patterning the interface. The intellectual merit of this work was to address this challenge using a combination of experimental methods developed specifically to control substrate structure, and to examine the resulting properties of the substrates via a combination of surface analytical tools, including atomic force microscopy (AFM) to explore structure and adhesion on model surfaces, as well as ionic liquid assembly, electrochemical AFM to examine how charges are controlled at the interfaces, and near-field scattering and Raman microspectroscopy to examine changes in the graphene optoelectronic properties. From studies of the electrochemical properties of ionic liquids on electrified graphene interfaces in the presence of water, it was found that organized layers of the ionic liquids (ILs) behave as highly concentrated electrolytes at the graphene-IL interface, trapping charge within a ca. 2 nm double layer, the stability of which can be altered by the uptake of water at the interface. These findings afford a means to advance the design of graphene-ionic liquid electrochemical based devices. From a mechanical standpoint, studies also revealed the friction coefficient at the lubricated tip-graphene contacts significantly depends on surface curvature (e.g. roughness), which can be used as a parameter to then tune friction. Roughness also impacts the organization of ILs and their ability to store charge. An additional outcome of this work was the unexpected discovery that under certain conditions for graphene on silica surfaces, the frictional properties of the surface could be controlled by light exposure, offering a unique opportunity to optically control friction which may have applications in next generation optical displays.

Beyond the fundamental research activities supported by this grant, additional broader impacts included providing students participating in this project cross-disciplinary education and training in areas of materials science and engineering, surface chemistry and mechanics. Diverse training such as this helps prepare students for US initiatives in advanced technologies, with students supported from this work going on to take positions in high technology business sectors (e.g. Brewer Science and Lynntech Inc). This project has also involved the development of outreach activities through hands on demonstrations aimed at elementary school and high school students on nanoscience. The PI and students involved with this project presented the results of this work in numerous scientific venues.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/11/2023
Modified by: James D Batteas
